snippet: Cruelty, a lack of services and an onerous tax system are driving people from areas controlled by the Islamic State, challenging its claim of being a government for the world’s Muslims.
abstract: Islamic State's goal of providing statehood for world's Muslims, complete with government and services, is buckling under strain of airstrikes and ground offenses, while group's promises to would-be citizens ring increasingly false; many living in ISIS-controlled areas, including those who pledged allegiance to group, are attempting to flee harsh conditions, lack of services and mounting taxes needed to finance operation.

byline.contributor: Karam Shoumali contributed reporting from Sanliurfa, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Cruelty, a lack of services and an onerous tax system are driving people from areas controlled by the Islamic State, challenging its claim of being a government for the world’s Muslims.

headline.main: ISIS Promise of Statehood Falling Far Short, Ex-Residents Say
